body:
What confuses me is what exactly constitutes "progressive", in political theory? I don't quite understand this word's usage in the slightest. So doesn't that imply anyone who believes in, say, anti-abortion laws, are "regressive", since that's the naturally the opposite of "progressive" policy that advocates for abortion rights? How is any belief more "progressive" than any other? In this specific scenario, the person apposing abortion think they are saving lives. Naturally they would firmly believe this is "progressive" as it would represent progress for them. But for some reason society indirectly defines this as "regressive" or backwards. Isn't progressive a completely idiosyncratic label?

i don't get it

body:
Calling an opposition to progressives or communists unjustified because it's "opinion" severely misses the mark. There's a fundamental difference of worldview between people who would use the law to compel behavior in order to alter society and those who believe force is only justified for the protection of rights.


"Can the law, whose necessary sanction is force, be reasonably employed upon anything beyond securing to every one his right? I defy anyone to remove it from this circle without perverting it, and consequently turning force against right. And as this is the most fatal, the most illogical social perversion that can possibly be imagined, it must be admitted that the true solution, so much sought after, of the social problem, is contained in these simple words‚ÄîLAW IS ORGANIZED JUSTICE.

Now it is important to remark, that to organize justice by law, that is to say by force, excludes the idea of organizing by law, or by force any manifestation whatever of human activity‚Äîlabor, charity, agriculture, commerce, industry, instruction, the fine arts, or religion; for any one of these organizings would inevitably destroy the essential organization. How, in fact, can we imagine force encroaching upon the liberty of citizens without infringing upon justice, and so acting against its proper aim? 

Here I am taking on the most popular prejudice of our time. It is not considered enough that law should be just, it must be philanthropic. It is not sufficient that it should guarantee to every citizen the free and inoffensive exercise of his faculties, applied to his physical, intellectual, and moral development; it is required to extend well-being, instruction, and morality, directly over the nation. ... And in fact it is impossible for me to separate the word fraternity from the word voluntary. I cannot possibly conceive fraternity legally enforced, without liberty being legally destroyed, and justice legally trampled under foot. Legal plunder has two roots: one of them, as we have already seen, is in human greed; the other is in misconceived philanthropy."

Marx saw capitalism as a transitory phase on the road to communism, not as its polar opposite like contemporary neoliberals and Marxists like to believe they are.
